questions.text: Pathology is a study of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Pathology literally translates as the study of suffering (Greek pathos = suffering, logos = study); and as applied to modern medicine, it is the study of disease. (Choice B)

Physiology is a study of animal function. (Choice D)

Microbiology is a study of all living things that are too small to be seen with the naked eye. For example study of bacteria, viruses, fungi, prions, protozoa, and algae. (Choice A)

Biochemistry is a study of the chemical interactions of living things. (Choice C)

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Pathology is the study of disease.

questions.text: Which one of the following is incorrect about the person in the image?
questions.solution:
Above image is of the great pathologist, RUDOLF VIRCHOW.

  • Rudolf Virchow was an eminent, multidisciplinary scientist, pathologist, and German politician, one of the most influential physicians in history. (Choice A)
  • He formed the cellular pathology, also has contributed to detecting some diseases (choice B) included over 2000 scientific papers.
  • Rudolf Virchow was labelled as "FATHER OF MODERN PATHOLOGY" & "Pope of medicine".
  • In 1855, he observed cell division under the microscope (Cell theory). He reasoned that all cells come from other pre-existing cells by cell division. (Choice C)

Reference: Rudolf Virchow (1821-1902) the father of modern pathology, D Laky, Romanian academy of medical sciences, revista medicala romana, volume LXV, Issue 4, 2018.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding interstitial matrix?
questions.solution:
• The ECM occurs in two basic forms:
    1. Interstitial matrix
    2. Basement membrane.
  • Interstitial matrix:
    • It occupies the spaces between stromal cells within connective tissue and between parenchymal epithelium and the underlying supportive vascular and smooth muscle structures in some organs.
    • Interstitial matrix is synthesized by mesenchymal cells(e.g., fibroblasts) (choice A)
    • It forms a three-dimensional, relatively amorphous, semi-fluid gel. (Choice B)
    • In some tissues, such as the gastrointestinal tract, urinary bladder, and periarterial soft tissues, fluid within matrix cushions tissue compression associated with peristalsis, urination, and pulsatile arterial bloodflow. (Choice C)
    • The major nonfluid constituents of the interstitial matrix are fibrillar and nonfibrillar collagens, as well as fibronectin, elastin, proteoglycans, hyaluronate, and other constituents.
  • Basement membrane:
    • Interstitial matrix within connective tissues becomes highly organized around epithelial cells, endothelial cells, and smooth muscle cells, where it forms basement membranes, specialized surfaces for cell growth.
    • Its components, which are synthesized by the overlying epithelium and underlying mesenchymal cells, form a flat lamellar mesh (although labeled as a membrane, it is quite porous).
    • The major constituents are nonfibrillar type IV collagen and laminin. (Choice D)
  • Interstitial matrix does not have constituents like type IV collagen and laminin.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The interstitial matrix is a component of the extracellular matrix (ECM) that fills the spaces between cells in connective tissues. It is composed of structural proteins like collagen, glycoproteins, and proteoglycans, providing mechanical support, facilitating cell adhesion, and regulating signaling pathways essential for tissue repair and maintenance.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a prototypical adhesive glycoproteins?
questions.solution:
• ECM (EXTRACELLULARMATRIX) components fall into 3 families:
    • Fibrous structural proteins such as collagens and elastin that confer tensile strength and recoil
    • Water-hydrated gels such as proteoglycans and hyaluronan that permit compressive resistance and lubrication
    • Adhesive glycoproteins such as fibronectin, laminin, integrin that connect ECM elements to one another and to cells
  • Prototypical ADHESIVE GLYCOPROTEINS & ADHESION MOLECULES:
    • Fibronectin(a major component of the interstitial ECM)
    • Laminin(a major constituent of basement membrane).
    • Integrins are representative of the adhesion receptors, also known as cell adhesion molecules (CAMs); the CAMs also include immunoglobulin family members, cadherins & selectins.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Adhesive glycoproteins are specialized molecules in the extracellular matrix that facilitate cell adhesion and communication with the ECM. Key examples include fibronectin, which links cells to collagen, and laminin, which anchors cells to the basement membrane. These glycoproteins play critical roles in tissue integrity, wound healing, and signal transduction.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about stem cells?
questions.solution:
• STEM CELLS have the dual property of
    • Being able to self renew
    • To give rise to differentiated cells and tissues.
  • Stem cells are maintained by self-renewal, which can involve two types of cell division:
    1. Asymmetric division refers to cell replication in which one daughter cell enters a differentiation pathway and gives Rise to mature cells, while the other remains undifferentiated and retains its self-renewal capacity. (Choice B)
    2. Symmetric division occurs when both daughter cells retain self-renewal capacity.
  • Two varieties of stem cells:
    • EMBRYONIC STEM (ES) CELLS (TOTIPOTENT STEM CELLS):
      • The most undifferentiated
      • Present in the inner cell mass of the blastocyst (choice A)
      • Virtually limitless cell renewal capacity
      • ES cells can be maintained for extended periods without differentiating, they can be induced under appropriate culture conditions to form specialized cells of all three germ cell layers.
    • TISSUE STEM CELLS (ADULT STEM CELLS) are
      • Found in intimate association with the differentiated cells of a given tissue.
      • Protected within specialized tissue microenvironments called STEM CELL NICHES. (Choice C)
      • Have a limited repertoire (lineage potential) of differentiated cells that they can generate. (Choice D)

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Stem cells are undifferentiated cells with the unique ability to self-renew and differentiate into specialized cell types. They are categorized into embryonic stem cells (pluripotent) and adult stem cells (multipotent), playing vital roles in development, tissue repair, and regenerative medicine.
